content.protection: 2 bolt anchor. Can be lead on gear or free soloed.

content.description: This route has been removed due to serious potential rockfall. It is advised not to climb left of Hands That Go Bump for this reason.
content.location: Left most line of bolts on Roadside Rock, just left of Hands That Go Bump (which has mechanical bolts as opposed to the newer routes that use glue ins)

climbs.name: Hands That Go Bump in the Night

content.description: Interesting 5.10 climbing. Anchors are not on the face so you have to top out when leading. If you are the FA please leave a comment as it would be nice to add some clip in anchors on the face that would be harder for the local teenagers to mess with.
content.protection: Anchors up top that teenagers have been known to remove before. Bolt spacing is good until it isn't-- it's run out up top.
content.location: Left-side on Roadside Rock with mechanical bolts (as opposed to the newer routes that all use glue ins).

content.description:
Start on the bolted arete to the right of Daddy's BMW and then go up and join Daddy's BMW at the ledge.

Shares anchor and last two bolts with Daddy's BMW. Some find it more puzzly than Daddy's BMW to the left, others don't. A good moderate lead for newer leaders.
content.protection: 5 bolts to clip in anchors. The anchor clips have been known to disappear on occasion, so make sure you see them there if you're not going to take draws for the anchor.
content.location: Right most line on Roadside Rock.

content.description:
Shares anchors with “Daddy’s BMW” and “Daddy’s Midlife Crisis”. This is Toprope only for now as no bolts have been placed yet and it still needs a bit of cleaning. However, the holds are all there and the rock is mostly solid.

Start left of “Daddy’s BMW”. Mantle up the small painted slab onto the ledge to enter the seam. Stem your way up the seam using positive holds to the small roof/flake. Follow the finger crack on the right side of the flake and mantle the small roof. Grab the jug to reach the top of the flake. Use discreet holds on the mossy slab and mantle the bulge before topping out at the anchor on your right.
content.protection: Two sets of anchors—two older bolt hangers on top and two newer looking glue in anchors on the face just below the others.
content.location: Giant painted rock on the side of the road. You cannot possibly miss it.

content.description: Climb starts between two aretes. Recommended beginner lead.
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2 bolt clip in anchor. The anchor clips have been known to disappear on occasion, so make sure you see them there if you're not going to take draws for the anchor.
content.location: On the far right of roadside rock, it's the left set of bolts that converge and then shares an anchor with Daddy's Midlife Crisis.

content.description:
Disclaimer:

I would be surprised if

nobody

has ever climbed this route before, but I cannot find it established online anywhere. I recommend a grade of 5.10c (if "Hand That Go Bump In The Night" is 5.10b, this is definitely more difficult).

Route:

Start on the corner of the arete. Follow the crack to the right, around the arete, onto the graffiti-buffed face and continue following the crack. When the crack ends, traverse left onto the moss-covered shelf and mantle to top out at the anchor. (See photo for details)
content.protection: Scramble up the left side of the rock to set up a two-bolt top rope anchor. Use the bolt hangers. I personally used a 30ft long 7mm cordelette and rigged a "magic-x" with stopper knots to create a self-equalizing anchor. The belayer belayed from the road's edge. You should ALWAYS use YOUR OWN best judgment to determine the best anchor setup and rigging for the route you intend to climb.
content.location: ​​​​40 foot rock on the side of the road with ample parking; it's hard to miss
